abstract.p: Harold L Pass letter says that as parent and psychologist he disagrees with suggstions in June 12 article on children and credit cards; says parents ought to assess child's need and knowledge, not poll other parents (S)

block.p: As a parent and a psychologist, I disagree with suggestions cited in your June 12 news article ''Brat Control on Easy Street.'' For example, when a child, rich or less affluent, requests a credit card, I would not advise polling other parents to see how many children actually have cards but rather assess the child's need and his knowledge and wisdom to use a credit card responsibly.

As a parent and a psychologist, I disagree with suggestions cited in your June 12 news article ''Brat Control on Easy Street.'' For example, when a child, rich or less affluent, requests a credit card, I would not advise polling other parents to see how many children actually have cards but rather assess the child's need and his knowledge and wisdom to use a credit card responsibly.

I am not naive and do believe that there are differences when parenting well-off and less affluent children. But I hope that we do not teach that there is a separate value system for the rich and for the poor.
HAROLD L. PASS Stony Brook, N.Y., June 12, 2000
The writer is an associate professor of clinical psychiatry, State University of New York at Stony Brook.
